sect2.title: 17.1 Introduction
sect2.para:
Veterinary technicians are considered caregiving professionals, and the emotional impact of caregiving professions has been increasingly explored throughout the last few decades. In the early 1990s, researchers sought to better understand why frontline healthcare professionals and service providers were exhibiting symptoms of post‐traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) without having experienced a traumatic event first‐hand. As a result of their findings, they coined the term compassion fatigue
ch0031-c17-bib-0001.

Compassion fatigue is often a result of work‐related stress, more specifically the psychological distress that happens when the worker is exposed to the suffering of othersch0031-c17-bib-0001. As time goes on and understanding of this subject evolves, the language is changing too. In this chapter, the phrase empathic strain (ES) will be used instead of compassion fatigue. This shift in terminology is due to emerging research that suggests empathic strain more accurately describes what caregiving professionals experience because of their jobs ch0031-c17-bib-0002. The term compassion fatigue implies that a professional can no longer provide the compassionate care required for their job role. In reality, caregiving professionals do not run out of compassion! What they might really be struggling with is providing empathy.

sect2.title: 17.2 Empathic Strain in Veterinary Practice
sect2.para: As discussed inChapter 6, empathy is to feel what another person feels. It involves actively resonating with another being's feelings to understand their perspective. Providing empathy is offering comfort on a deeper level; it is what establishes a connection between the helper and who they help ch0031-c17-bib-0002. Empathy allows technicians to relate to and share in their clients' and patients’ experiences ch0031-c17-bib-0002. When a technician can empathize with who they are helping, they can provide compassionate care (Figure 17.1).

Empathy can be a double‐edged sword. For instance, a level of detachment from distressing situations can be healthy, but too little empathy may create a disconnect between clients and technicians that disrupts communication and care. However, if technicians empathize too deeply, they may risk becoming overly involved in a case. This emotional entanglement can blur the lines between their own feelings and those of the patients or clients they are caring for ch0031-c17-bib-0002. As a result, it can become difficult for them to emotionally detach from their work, potentially affecting their mental well‐being and their ability to effectively engage with both clients and patients.

sect2.para: Empathic strain also correlates strongly with burnout; this is likely another familiar term for technicians. Burnout is a direct result of occupational stress and is seen as emotional tiredness, detachment, and a reduced sense of achievement in one's work rolech0031-c17-bib-0003. Burnout has to do with the sense of control and satisfaction an individual feels in their work role. Table 17.1 includes common signs and symptoms of ES; it is not an exhaustive list.

sect2.title: 17.2.1 Causes of Empathic Strain
sect2.para: Empathic strain is notably prevalent in high‐trauma fields such as healthcare, where occupational stress is intense. This strain is a byproduct of occupational, environmental, and personal factorsch0031-c17-bib-0004.

listitem.para: Occupational: challenges such as extended or unpredictable hours, heavy caseloads, moral dilemmas in decision‐making (moral distress), challenging interactions with clients and patients, unforeseen patient outcomes, and a scarcity of staffing and resources.

Environmental: both the professional setting and broader external factors, including conflicts with colleagues, the physical workspace, and global occurrences such as pandemics, can add an additional layer of stress.
Personal: individuals with a high degree of empathy, personal traumas, mental and physical health concerns, and other pressures can be particularly susceptible to ES.

sect2.para: For a technician, these challenges may be compounded by the emotional toll of caring for animals in distress and guiding distressed caregivers through end‐of‐life (EOL) decisions and planning. This is where the concept of moral distress becomes particularly relevant.

sect2.title: 17.2.2 The Role of Moral Distress in Empathic Strain
sect2.para: Moral distress refers to the stress response an individual experiences when faced with decisions that challenge their personal ethics, values, and belief systemch0031-c17-bib-0005. Moral distress can be seen often among veterinary personnel, especially in EOL scenarios. Morally distressing situations may leave technicians feeling powerless, angry, or guilty (Case Study 17.1).

sidebar.title: Case Study 17.1 Emily, the Browns, and Muffy
sidebar.para: Emily is a recent graduate of a veterinary technician program. She has been working in a general practice clinic since finishing school seven months ago. Over the past several months, she has gotten to know the Browns and their cat, Muffy. Muffy presented to the clinic with dehydration and weight loss. The veterinarian diagnosed Muffy with diabetes and prescribed insulin and a diet change. Emily educated the Browns on Muffy's insulin injections and the new feeding schedule that would help Muffy maintain steady blood glucose levels. The Browns and Emily were in touch regularly, especially in the early days of Muffy's diagnosis. Despite their efforts, Muffy's blood glucose was erratic. After many changes in insulin dosing the veterinarian recommended a more expensive, but hopefully more effective type of insulin. The Browns expressed their concern about the cost of the insulin and decided to euthanize Muffy.

Emily assists with Muffy's euthanasia, but as she is caring for Muffy's remains, she feels a mix of anger and helplessness. Why couldn't the Browns have tried another drug? Was this her fault? Had she, Emily, done enough to educate the family about Muffy's needs? Should she have offered to take the cat in herself rather than allow her to be euthanized? When she voices some of these thoughts to her colleagues, they tell her that events like this are all part of working in veterinary medicine, and she'll just have to get used to it.

para.emphasis: In what way is Emily presenting with moral distress?
Why might the advice her colleagues gave her about “getting used to it,” not be sustainable for Emily long term?

sect2.para: Addressing ES calls for technicians to gain a deeper understanding of how they are impacted by their stressors on a personal level, but also on an organizational and systemic level. This chapter does not propose a “quick fix” but rather acknowledges the complexity of the systems within which technicians operate. It aims to provide a basic understanding of the constructs impacting technicians and practical tools for navigating these challenges.

sect2.title: 17.3 Personal Approaches to Mitigating Empathic Strain
sect2.para: Being proactive in addressing ES on an individual level begins with self‐awareness. Self‐awareness can be enhanced through the practice of self‐care, but self‐care extends beyond temporary relaxation and requires a holistic approach. Holistic self‐care involves recognizing and nurturing all aspects of a person’s well‐being, including their psychological, biological, spiritual, and cultural dimensions. When one area is affected, it impacts the others.

Self‐care is essential, but it is sometimes easier said than done – it requires practice and patience. Technicians who prioritize caring for themselves will develop a clearer understanding of what triggers ES, how it affects their overall well‐being, and what specific self‐care strategies they need to regain balance. These activities may range from physical exercise to emotional strategies such as engaging in hobbies, accessing mental health resources, or practicing mindfulness.

sect2.title: 17.3.1 Empathic Strain Personal Warning System
sect2.para: To further enhance their self‐awareness and understand the impact of ES, veterinary personnel can develop a personalized “warning system”ch0031-c17-bib-0003. This system helps to recognize early signs of ES and enables technicians to take proactive steps to address it (see Figure 17.2).

This scale is labeled from a “green zone” into a “red zone.” The green zone is when an individual feels their best self. This might be characterized as sleeping well, taking breaks at work, enjoying hobbies or time with friends, feeling connected and socializing with coworkers, or feeling willing and able to engage with clients during difficult conversationsch0031-c17-bib-0003.

The red zone represents when a person is feeling their worst. This might look like the signs and symptoms inTable 17.1 (e.g. calling in sick for work often, isolating oneself from coworkers, dreading dealing with clients and patients, conflicts with family or friends, and headaches) ch0031-c17-bib-0003. Having a warning system in place serves three important purposes for technicians:

listitem.para: Identification: Technicians can identify what signs and symptoms exist when feeling good or bad. This provides a better sense of how stress manifests and when they might be entering the “red zone.”
Reflection: Allows technicians to observe why they are entering the red zone. Perhaps there are certain triggers or events that lead them there, personally or professionally.
Strategies: Technicians can then take that information and start to identify strategies that can help them move back into the green zone.

sect2.title: 17.3.2 Mindfulness Practices
sect2.para: Mindfulness means being intentionally aware of oneself and surroundings in the present momentch0031-c17-bib-0008. It requires observing and acknowledging feelings, thoughts, and bodily sensations without judgment ch0031-c17-bib-0008. Being mindful is a great way to learn more about oneself, including what triggers different reactions and emotions. Being aware of these responses and why they happen aids in finding perspective and coping effectively during challenging situations.

Veterinary technicians can use mindfulness exercises to help emotionally and physically regulate themselves at work. In moments where a technician feels overwhelmed or stressed, they can pause and find a quiet space such as a break room or bathroom, and practice these exercises.Table 17.2 and Figure 17.3 show two examples of mindfulness techniques that can be done anywhere and only take a few minutes. Implementing these techniques allows technicians to engage in mindfulness throughout their daily activities.

Table 17.2

Acknowledge
FIVE things you can see: This can be anything you see around you, such as a pen on the table or the color of the wall.
Acknowledge FOUR things you can touch: Perhaps it is the fabric of your scrubs or your hair.
Acknowledge THREE things you can hear: Any external sounds, such as a dog barking or a phone ringing.
Acknowledge TWO things you can smell: Maybe it is the smell of flowers or nature if you step outside or even the smell of soap in the bathroom.
Acknowledge ONE thing you can taste: A sip of water or a piece of gum.

sect2.title: 17.3.3 Professional Support and Mentorship
sect2.para: Professional support is another useful way to help prevent and manage ES. These supports can help technicians develop healthy coping mechanisms, improve emotional resilience, bolster professional skill sets, network and connect with peers, promote mindfulness, and access resources that benefit physical and mental health. Technicians can find these resources through veterinary mental health initiatives, employee assistance programs (EAPs) or workplace benefits, and regulatory and professional associations.

listitem.para: individual counseling from a licensed or registered mental health professional;
peer support groups facilitated by a mental health professional or hosted by professional associations;
wellness programs such as educational workshops.

sect2.para: Mentorship is an effective strategy for managing occupational stressors that contribute to emotional strain. Seasoned professionals may provide guidance, share valuable insights, and help develop the skills of those who are newer to the field. This supportive relationship may assist in professional growth and offer a constructive outlet for addressing work challenges that cause stress or overwhelmch0031-c17-bib-0010. Mentorship programs have been shown to help with retention, job satisfaction, and reducing ES ch0031-c17-bib-0010.

sect2.title: 17.4 Organizational Strategies for Enhancing Well‐Being
sect2.para: It is important that technicians take active steps to nurture their individual selves. However, veterinary organizations must also create spaces where staff can do this effectively. The onus for preventing and mitigating ES does not fall solely on the technician, it must be reinforced by their workspaces. Organizations that put effort into a healthy, cohesive workplace are creating a positive culture for their staff, which can help with staff retention, client engagement, patient care, and improved business practices. This chapter does not have the scope to deep dive into the larger systemic issues that are deeply rooted in veterinary medicine and have a massive impact on the mental health and well‐being of its professionals. There is much work to do to competently address these systems and create healthy and safe spaces for the people working within them. The way veterinary organizations operate is one piece of this puzzle.

sect2.title: 17.4.1 Leadership’s Role in Ensuring Psychological Safety
sect2.para: Veterinary organizational leadership is responsible for implementing wellness strategies. Technicians can act as advocates for the development of these initiatives. A psychologically healthy veterinary practice is one where employees feel genuinely heard, their insights are valued and taken seriously, and they receive strong support for both their mental and physical well‐being. Practices that provide opportunities for the development of both clinical and communication skills are creating a work environment where professional growth and personal well‐being are prioritized. Leadership should ask themselves the following question: can employees ask questions, give feedback, and express concerns without fear of being humiliated, talked down to, or punished? If not, the workplace isn't psychologically safe. Employees should know that they will receive mutual trust, respect, and support from their team and leadership.

sect2.para: Supporting mental well‐being in the workplace is a huge part of creating safe workspaces. EAPs and employee benefits are valuable resources that help individuals deal with issues affecting their job performance, health, or mental well‐being. Easy access to counseling services is important so that staff can address concerns related to emotional stress. Support from leadership and senior management is key to raising awareness and encouraging the use of these resources. Furthermore, regular team meetings that allow everyone to share their thoughts provide technicians with opportunities to participate in decision‐making and shape workplace culture (Figure 17.4). Managers should also review the workday structure, including hours worked, breaks, and vacation time. When leadership reinforces boundaries and encourages breaks, it helps the team manage heavy workloads and long hours. Leadership and technicians can visit the websites of their regional associations such as the Canadian Veterinary Medical Association and American Veterinary Medical Association to learn more about how to implement psychological health and safety in the workplace.

sect2.title: 17.4.2 Developing Policies and Procedures
sect2.para: For an organization to address ES, it’s important to have clear policies and protocols on EOL care. A policy is a guideline that outlines a course of action, while a protocol provides specific steps to follow in certain situations. These tools are valuable because they help improve and inform clinical practice and communication during high‐stress situationsch0031-c17-bib-0011. Policies and protocols that emphasize respect and dignity in EOL care give technicians and other staff clear instructions for actions to take in difficult situations, which can reduce anxiety in these scenarios. Policies and procedures that reflect the team’s values and professional regulations provide guidance in decision‐making. For example, practices should consider having guidelines for ethically challenging and emotional cases such as behavioral euthanasia, reporting animal cruelty/abuse, and client safety concerns like suicide. These policies and procedures can be essential for the safety of the veterinary team, clients, and patients.

sect2.title: 17.4.3 Peer Debriefing
sect2.para: Debriefing amongst peers is an effective way of addressing ES [ch0031-c17-bib-0012, ch0031-c17-bib-0013]. Peer debriefing is a structured conversation between colleagues aimed at processing challenging or distressing events; it is not the same as venting. Debriefing can be conducted formally or informally. A formal debrief is scheduled with a larger group of people, while an informal debrief is more casual, happening spontaneously with another person (see Pro Tip 17.1).

In veterinary settings, debriefing helps staff reflect on both the medical and emotional aspects of their work, particularly after difficult cases or distressing events, such as the loss of a patient or difficult interactions with clients. Specifically, low‐impact debriefing (LID) is recommended. LID is a practice designed for caregiving professionals to share and process both secondary and direct traumatic experiences in a way that minimizes harm [ch0031-c17-bib-0012, ch0031-c17-bib-0013]. A key part of LID is preventing “contagion,” which refers to the unintended spread of secondary trauma from professionals to their peers and family members when sharing details of traumatic events (Case Study 17.2). By using LID, veterinary professionals can participate in debriefing sessions that focus on emotional safety, reducing the risk of “contagion” or increased stress (Table 17.3).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 17.1 Debriefing Training
sidebar.para: Organizations such as the Crisis and Trauma Resource Institute offer trauma‐informed training such asCritical Incident Group Debriefing. It is necessary to receive proper training before engaging in larger group debriefs or to have a mental health professional facilitate this.

sidebar.title: Case Study 17.2 George and Jessy
sidebar.para: George is a technician at an emergency and after‐hours practice. After a particularly hard shift where George attended to and then euthanized a patient who was hit by a vehicle, he decides to talk to his colleague Jessy, hoping to alleviate some of the challenging thoughts and feelings he experienced by sharing the story. When George finishes his shift, he launches into his day at work and shares the details of the case with Jessy, then heads home for the evening.

Jessy, on the other hand, did not feel prepared to listen to George’s story. Jessy feels disturbed and upset by what George described. Jessy had their own stressful day at work and now feels burdened by this imagery and scenario. Jessy spends the evening trying to numb themselves by watching television, so they don’t have to think about it.

para.emphasis: How might George have approached sharing his experience differently to avoid “contagion” to Jessy?

sect2.title: 17.4.4 Integrating Veterinary Social Work
sect2.para: Veterinary social work (VSW) is a specialized field of social work that addresses the human needs arising at the intersection of veterinary medicine and social workch0031-c17-bib-0014. VSW focuses on fostering the well‐being of both humans and animals. Professionals in this field often work within five interconnected pillars that address critical aspects of the human–animal relationship (HAR):

listitem.para: The Link Between Human and Animal Violence
Animal‐Related Grief and Bereavement
Animal‐Assisted Interventions
Intentional Well‐Being for Animal‐Related Professionals
The Environmental Impact on the HAR

sect2.para: The growing number of professionals in this field led to the establishment of the International Association of Veterinary Social Work (IAVSW), an organization dedicated to advancing these pillars through advocacy, education, research, and community‐buildingch0031-c17-bib-0014. By acknowledging the essential role animals play in people's lives and the systems they are part of, VSW emphasizes the need for interdisciplinary collaboration that supports not only animals but also the people who care for them – both clients and veterinary professionals.

In veterinary medicine settings, VSW professionals fulfill diverse roles. They work directly with clients navigating treatment decisions, quality of life considerations, or EOL planning for their animals. They also collaborate closely with veterinary staff to facilitate communication with clients, provide psychoeducation, address moral distress and ES, and advocate for systemic changes that promote mental health and well‐being in the veterinary medicine industrych0031-c17-bib-0015. While not all veterinary practices can employ a full‐time social worker, they can connect with organizations such as IAVSW to access support, resources, and training tailored to their needs.

listitem.para: ES has a significant impact on the veterinary profession.
ES is complex and affected by personal, occupational, and environmental factors alongside the unique challenges posed by moral distress.
Veterinary technicians navigate high‐pressure environments that require demonstrating empathy for clients and patients while attending to their own emotional needs and well‐being.
Mitigating ES demands a comprehensive approach on an individual and organizational level.
Individual ES management strategies include mindfulness and self‐awareness practices and accessing professional support.

Systemic and organizational solutions for ES include leadership that prioritizes psychological safety, clear protocols for high‐stress scenarios, and debriefing frameworks that contribute to healthier work environments.
The integration of VSW can reinforce a culture of care.
17.1 Emily, the Browns, and Muffy
17.2 George and Jessy

Emily may be experiencing moral distress because she feels conflicted about the ethical implications of Muffy’s euthanasia. Her personal values and beliefs around Muffy's care clash with the decision of her clients to euthanize. She feels powerless, questions whether she did enough to support the clients, and even considers whether she should have taken responsibility for Muffy herself. These feelings of guilt, helplessness, and anger align with moral distress.

This advice dismisses Emily’s emotional response and invalidates her concerns, which may lead to feelings of isolation from her coworkers or self‐doubt about her concerns. Emily may not feel she is able to discuss these challenging scenarios with her coworkers due to their responses, which may impact her mental health and job performance.

To avoid emotional contagion and respect Jessy's capacity to process challenging stories, George could have approached the situation using the LID steps! By applying these strategies, George could have sought support while minimizing the risk of emotional contagion and respecting Jessy's emotional limits.
